As an AI assistant, I don't have the most up-to-date information on Reebok's current practices, but I can provide some general information on how companies may implement waste management practices in their factories.

Most companies have specific departments or teams that are responsible for waste management and reduction. These teams are typically made up of environmental engineers or specialists who have knowledge of waste reduction strategies and technologies. They work closely with manufacturing teams to identify areas where waste can be reduced or eliminated.

To implement these waste management practices, companies may also set specific targets for reducing waste, such as reducing the amount of waste sent to landfills by a certain percentage or recycling a certain percentage of waste materials. Reebok could also provide training to employees to help them understand and implement waste reduction strategies.

In addition, many companies also partner with third-party organizations or suppliers to help manage and reduce waste. For example, they may contract with waste management companies that specialize in recycling or repurposing materials to help ensure that waste is properly disposed of or reused.

Integrating waste management practices into different areas of the company can also help promote a culture of sustainability and waste reduction, which can lead to long-term benefits for both the company and the environment.
